Thanks a bunch for the info Ken.

I ended up going with a set of addition 1=
2 positions, 6 on each side. The
tournament uses the original 9 positions, =
adds a single additional piece of
food at each of the 12 alternate position=
s, and then goes through all the
combinations of positions with 2 additiona=
l food pieces. This give me 79
variations of food layout, times 2 for start=
ing both left and right. Should
be good enough for my purposes I think.


-=
Drew



On Sun, Oct 9, 2011 at 7:39 PM, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:=


> **
>
>
>
>
> Hi Drew, sorry for the delay in this answer. After 7 years=
 going back and
> trying to understand the old code for setting up these co=
nfigurations is a
> challenge. I believe what is going on is that we divide=
 the left side of the
> board into a 3 column and 4 row grid (giving 12 cel=
ls). The same is done for
> the right side of the board (so 12 cells there)=
. For the 144 combinations,
> we step through all the 12 possible positions=
 on the left side and place a
> good there for the outer loop, and all the =
12 possible positions on the
> right side and place a food there on the inn=
er loop. Recall that each
> configuration involves only the placement of tw=
o pieces of food (one on the
> left side and one on the right), and all the=
 other food are in their usual
> static positions at the start. Then we get=
 to 288 by flipping the starting
> positions of the robots themselves and d=
oing all the 144 configurations
> again.
>
> The one thing I'm a little unc=
ertain about is if it was really 3 by 4, or
> perhaps 4 by 3 on each side. =
Or even 6 by 2, or maybe 2 by 6. I'm but I
> don't think it really matters =
for the purposes of this test since the point
> is just to try a lot of dif=
ferent starting scenarios so the exact columns
> and rows shouldn't be crit=
ical.
>
> I hope this helps,
>
> ken
>

Thanks a bunch for the info Ken.=A0<div><br></div><div>I ended up going wit=
h a set of addition 12 positions, 6 on each side. The tournament uses the o=
riginal 9 positions, adds a single additional piece of food at each of the =
12 alternate positions, and then goes through all the combinations of posit=
ions with 2 additional food pieces. This give me 79 variations of food layo=
ut, times 2 for starting both left and right. Should be good enough for my =
purposes I think.=A0</div>

<div><br></div><div><br></div><div>-Drew</div><=
div><div><br></div><div><br><div><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Sun, Oct=

s.utexas.edu">kstanley@...</a>></span> wrote:<br>

<blockquote=
 class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc soli=
d;padding-left:1ex;">


<u></u>










<div style=3D"background-color:#f=
ff">

    <div>
      
      
      <p><b=
r>
<br>
Hi Drew, sorry for the delay in this answer.  After 7 years going b=
ack and trying to understand the old code for setting up these configuratio=
ns is a challenge.  I believe what is going on is that we divide the left s=
ide of the board into a 3 column and 4 row grid (giving 12 cells).  The sam=
e is done for the right side of the board (so 12 cells there).  For the 144=
 combinations, we step through all the 12 possible positions on the left si=
de and place a good there for the outer loop, and all the 12 possible posit=
ions on the right side and place a food there on the inner loop.  Recall th=
at each configuration involves only the placement of two pieces of food (on=
e on the left side and one on the right), and all the other food are in the=
ir usual static positions at the start.  Then we get to 288 by flipping the=
 starting positions of the robots themselves and doing all the 144 configur=
ations again.<br>


<br>
The one thing I'm a little uncertain about is =
if it was really 3 by 4, or perhaps 4 by 3 on each side.  Or even 6 by 2, o=
r maybe 2 by 6.  I'm but I don't think it really matters for the pu=
rposes of this test since the point is just to try a lot of different start=
ing scenarios so the exact columns and rows shouldn't be critical.<br>
=


<br>
I hope this helps,<br>
<br>
ken</p><div class=3D"im"><br>
<br>
--- I=
